question: Question_07_(b)
statement:
Let \emph{E} be the ellipse \emph{x\textsuperscript{2} +
k\textsuperscript{2}y\textsuperscript{2} = 1}, where \emph{k} is a
constant with \emph{k} $\geq$ 1. Let \emph{S} be the region inside the
circle \emph{x\textsuperscript{2} + y\textsuperscript{2} = 1,} outside
\emph{E}, and above the \emph{x}-axis.

Find all values of \emph{k} such that the centroid (centre of mass) of
\emph{S} lies inside \emph{S} (i.e. outside \emph{E}). You may use the
result of
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH101/April 2008/Question 7 (a)}{part
(a)}.
sols:
A picture when \emph{k} is 2 is drawn below.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{MATH101Apr2008Q7b.jpeg}
\caption{MATH101Apr2008Q7b.jpeg}
\end{figure}

To compute the area of \emph{S}, we actually don't need to do any more
work. Notice that the area of the blue circle when \emph{y} is greater
than 0 is half the area of the unit circle which is $\tfrac{\pi}{2}$.
Now, the area of the ellipse when \emph{y} is greater than 0 is again
half the area of the ellipse, which by the previous problem is
$\tfrac{\pi(1)}{2}(\tfrac{1}{k}) = \tfrac{\pi}{2k}$. Hence, the area of
\emph{S} is

$A = \frac{\pi}{2} - \frac{\pi}{2k} = \frac{\pi}{2}\left(1 - \frac{1}{k} \right).$

Now, notice that when \emph{x} is 0, then the two points on the ellipse
are $y = \pm \tfrac{1}{k}$. So the one lying in the upper half of the
plane is $y = \tfrac{1}{k}$. The question asks when is the centroid
outside of E (so inside S). By symmetry, the \emph{x} coordinate of the
centroid is 0. So all we need to do is figure out when
$\bar{y} \geq \tfrac{1}{k}$ (NOTE: There is a bit of ambiguity in the
sense that is something on the boundary of S and E inside S or outside
of E - I suspect students using greater than or equal to vs just greater
than would earn full marks but it is something we should be a bit
careful with). In any case, we compute when

\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{k} \leq \bar{y} &= \frac{1}{2A}\int_{a}^{b}(f(x)^{2}-g(x)^{2})\, dx
\end{align*}

Here, the upper curve is the positive half of the circle so

$\displaystyle f(x) = \sqrt{1 - x^{2}}$

and the lower curve is the upper half of the ellipse so

$\displaystyle g(x) = \sqrt{\frac{1-x^{2}}{k^{2}}}.$

The picture also clearly shows that we are integrating from
$-1 \leq x \leq 1$ (we could have explicitly found these points of
intersection as well). Thus, we have

\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{k} \leq \bar{y} &= \frac{1}{2A}\int_{a}^{b}(f(x)^{2}-g(x)^{2})\, dx \\
&= \frac{1}{2\cdot\frac{\pi}{2}\left(1 - \frac{1}{k} \right)}\int_{-1}^{1}(1-x^{2}-\frac{1-x^{2}}{k^{2}})\, dx \\
&= \frac{1}{\pi\cdot \frac{k-1}{k}}\int_{-1}^{1}(1-x^{2})\left( 1 -\frac{1}{k^{2}}\right) )\, dx
\end{align*}

where in the last step we factored out a $1-x^{2}$. Pulling out the
terms depending only on \emph{k} in the integral and using the fact that
the integral is the integral of an even function over a symmetric
interval yields

\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{k} \leq \bar{y} &= \frac{1}{\pi\cdot \frac{k-1}{k}}\left( 1 -\frac{1}{k^{2}}\right)2\int_{0}^{1}(1-x^{2}) )\, dx\\
&= \frac{2k}{\pi(k-1)}\cdot\frac{k^{2}-1}{k^{2}}\left. \left(x - \frac{x^{3}}{3}\right)\right|_{0}^{1}\\
&= \frac{2k}{\pi(k-1)}\cdot\frac{(k+1)(k-1)}{k^{2}}\left(1 - \frac{1}{3}\right)\\
&= \frac{4(k+1)}{3\pi k}
\end{align*}

Using the inequality derived above, we have

\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{k} &\leq  \frac{4(k+1)}{3\pi k} \\
3\pi &\leq 4(k+1) \\
\frac{3\pi - 4}{4} &\leq k
\end{align*}

and this completes the proof.
hints:
The coordinates of the centroid are computed using the formulas

\[\bar{x}=\frac{1}{A}\int_{a}^{b}xf(x)dx\]

and

\[\bar{y}=\frac{1}{A}\int_{a}^{b}\frac{1}{2}(f(x))^2dx\]

where

\[A = \int_{a}^{b}f(x)\, dx\]
